Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: Three card brag is a simple form of poker; you are dealt only three cards and these you can't change. If you don't look at your cards you're a `blind man' and you only put in half the stake. Three of any kind is the highest you can get: the odds are four hundred and twenty- five to one. Then it's a running flush - you know, all the same suit running in order; then a straight, then a flush, then a pair, and finally whatever the highest card you are holding. There are some tell- tale signs that are valuable; I am not going to tell you them because it took me long enough to learn them, but these can only help a player, not make one. So you want to play?

Speaker: serg
Dialogue: I hope I am not interrupting. Comfortable, Edward?

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: I haven't slept for forty-eight hours, got a dozen broken ribs, can feel a case of the flu coming on and . . .

Speaker: serg
Dialogue: All right, all right, don't think I wouldn't like to get rid of you; but before I do, I need to know what's going on, son.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: If you think you're in the dark, I am in a black hole, blindfolded.

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: See these goods, they never seen daylight, moonlight, Israelite, Fanny- by-the-gas-light. If you can't see value here today you're not up here shopping, you're up here shoplifting. Take a bag, take a bag. I took a bag, I took a bag home last night and she cost a lot more than ten pounds I can tell ya. Tell me if I am going too cheap. Not ninety, not eighty, not forty, half that and half that again, that's right, ten pounds. Don't think 'cos it's sealed up it's an empty box. The only man who sells empty boxes is the undertaker, and by the look of some of you here today I would make more money with me measuring tape.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: Bargain, that's a bloody bargain if I ever heard one. Ten pounds you say? I'll have five.

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: Excuse me misses, sorry sir, ladies first and all that.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: Bacon!

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: Ed can run fast, talk fast, eat fast, and play cards fast, but he's fucking slow when it comes to spotting the roz.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: The reason he is called BACON is he spent so much of his youth in the police station that people thought he was one of them. But he is a big boy now and it is time to move on.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What are you talking about? I am bloody skinny, pal.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: Of course you are. All right, Ed.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: Nick the Greek, always a pleasure. All right Tom, what you been eating?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Please, both join me in my orifice.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: How much did you say it was, Tom?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You know how much it is, Nick.

Speaker: nick
Dialogue: And that does include the amp?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You know it doesn't include the amp.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What have you come as?

Speaker: soap
Dialogue: Cupid stupid! That's the last time I am getting any more fruit off you Tom. Call that fresh? There was more small hairy armoured things in your fruit than there was fruit. You should open a butcher's, not a grocer's.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: If you will order stuff that comes from Kat-Man-Fucking-Du don't be surprised if your fruit picks up a few tourists en route. ~ Never mind that, what about the money?

Speaker: soap
Dialogue: Get your fingers out of my soup!

Dialogue: Soap is called Soap because he likes to keep his hands clean of any unlawful behaviour. He is proud of his job, and even more proud that it's legal.

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: He's a stroppy sod but he's got more balls than a golfer, only he doesn't know it. ' * Cut from completed film.

Dialogue: Are you sure you can afford twenty-five?

Dialogue: Well that depends on how you look at it. I can afford it as long as I see it again, if that's what you mean. You got the rest from the fat man and Bacon?

Dialogue: Who's this fat man, then?

Dialogue: Bacon, the fat man and myself, and it's time to make a call to Harry.

Speaker: hatchet

Dialogue: A hundred grand.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: You see it's not easy to take a seat at this table; the money involved has to be a hundred grand upwards and there is no shortage of punters.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: The man who decides if you can play is this man Harry, or Hatchet Harry as some including himself like to call him.

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: Well if you got it, you got it. Now, if you don't mind . . .

Speaker: soap
Dialogue: When the old bastard is not playing cards he's chasing a thousand debts that ill-fated individuals owe for an array of reasons.

Dialogue: Sex and sleaze and antique shotguns are all deep and dear in Harry's stone cold heart.

Dialogue: What's this EDDY like, then?

Dialogue: The Baptist got his name from drowning people for Hatchet.

Dialogue: Twenty-five from me, Tom, Soap and yourself; a hundred grand to the pound. You don't need to count it.

Dialogue: So, a reasonable return should be in the region of one hundred and twenty, for twenty-five grand invested. That's going on previous experiences.

Dialogue: Whatever it's going on, it's still enough to send you on a cooking course.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: Because it's cheap like a budgie.

Dialogue: What do you mean?

Dialogue: He means they're thieving dogs.

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: I mean when they are not picking peanuts out of poop, they're ripping off unfortunate souls of their hard-earned drugs.

Speaker: dog
Dialogue: No you prat, that's for me.

Speaker: dog
Dialogue: How many times do I have to explain this to you, Plank? You find a job worth doing and you will find your share improving . . . Now do you have a problem with that?

Dialogue: How long has he been in there, son?

Dialogue: Son, have a look under that one.

Dialogue: Try that one.

Dialogue: Sleeping like a baby.

Dialogue: This is one of those high-powered numbers, isn't it?

Dialogue: Mind your language in front of my boy.

Dialogue: That includes blasphemy as well. Now tell me, John . . .

Dialogue: I say, hold on.

Dialogue: Did I say speak? And it's Mr Harry to you . . . Now don't disappoint me and chose your words carefully. You may speak.

Dialogue: Son, have a look in his locker.

Speaker: big chris
Dialogue: Yeah, all right.

Dialogue: He's not poor. Five hundred and sixty pounds and that's just in his wallet . . . Fuckin' 'ell John, you always walk around with that in your pocket?

Speaker: big chris
Dialogue: Oi! Next time you use language like that, boy, you'll wish you hadn't!

Speaker: little chrts
Dialogue: Sorry, Dad.

Speaker: big chris
Dialogue: Right, well, put the rest of the stuff in that, son. You can go home in a plastic bag tonight, John. You owe what you owe arid before this tan has faded, you want to have paid.

Dialogue: What you telling us for? The only thing I care about is whether you get your rest in.

Dialogue: Tom, you're all heart.

Dialogue: Listen cooky, you want to make sure that man rests before he plays; it's in all our interests.

Dialogue: All right lads? How's things? How's it going, Soap? Cooking all right? Where's that son of mine?

Dialogue: Charles, why have we got this cage?

Dialogue: Er, fertilizer.

Dialogue: You went out six hours ago to buy a money counter and you come back carrying two bags of fertilizer. Alarm bells are ringing, Willy.

Speaker: willy

Speaker: winston
Dialogue: We also need a fucking money counter, William! We have to get the money out by Thursday and I'll be buggered if I am counting it . . . and if you have to get your sodding fertilizer, couldn't you be a little more subtle?

Dialogue: What do you mean?

Dialogue: I mean we grow copious amounts of ganja, and you don't look like your average hort-er-fucking-culturalist, that's what I mean, Willy.

Dialogue: Oh, you must be the brains then. That's right, guns that fire shot . . . Make sure you bring everything from inside the gun cabinet. There will be a load of guns, that's all I want. I'll pay you when you deliver. Everything outside the cabinet you can keep; it's yours.

Dialogue: Oh, thanks very much. And there had better be something there for us.

Dialogue: Antiques? What the fuck do we know about antiques? We rob post offices and steal cars, what the fuck do we know about antiques?

Speaker: barry
Dialogue: Careful, remember who's giving you this job.

Dialogue: Fucking Northern monkeys.

Dialogue: Never mind son, you just might meet him if you carry on like that.

Dialogue: I heard this place was rough.

Dialogue: What sort of a pub is this then?

Dialogue: What's that?

Dialogue: A cocktail, you asked for a cocktail.

Dialogue: No, I asked you to give me a refreshing drink. I wasn't expecting a fucking rainforest; you could fall in love with an orang-utan in that.

Dialogue: You want a pint, go to the pub.

Dialogue: I thought this was a pub.

Dialogue: It's a Samoan pub.

Dialogue: Well whatever it is, could you get your man to turn the TV down?

Dialogue: You ask him if you like, but I would leave him to it if I was you.

Dialogue: No.

Speaker: soap
Dialogue: This is the English-Brazil game, isn't it?

Speaker: croupier
Dialogue: This is three card brag, gentlemen. That means that three threes is the highest, then three aces and then running down accordingly; then it's a running flush, a run, a flush, then a pair: An open man can't see a blind man, and it will cost you twice the anti to see your opponent. Don't fuck around, fellas; you all know the rules and you know I won't stand for it.

Speaker: frazer
Dialogue: What sort of shirt is that then, Ed? 'Three hundred open.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: The type of shirt that has buttons on the front and collars at the top, Frazer. One hundred and fifty blind.

Speaker: don
Dialogue: Three hundred and fifty open.

Speaker: phil
Dialogue: Fold.

Dialogue: Three hundred and fifty open.

Dialogue: You're the only fella in London who wears shirts like that. Three hundred and fifty open.

Dialogue: No Frazer, it's just I'm the only classy fella you have had the pleasure of seeing in London. One hundred and seventy-five blind.

Speaker: don
Dialogue: Four hundred open.

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: Four hundred open.

Speaker: frazer
Dialogue: Eight hundred. Like that, do ya, son?

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: When my knees stop knocking I'll live with it. Four hundred blind.

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: Listen ladies, this is cards. Men play cards, you want to talk soft you should be at the fucking hairdressers, so shut up and play.  I fold.

Speaker: frazer
Dialogue: Two thousand open.

Dialogue: One thousand blind.

Speaker: don
Dialogue: Two thousand open.

Dialogue: Deep end, eh? Fold.

Dialogue: Two thousand blind.

Dialogue: You what?

Dialogue: Well, you going to play?

Speaker: don
Dialogue: Fucking right I am going to play. Three thousand, there.

Speaker: croupier
Dialogue: Four thousand to an open man, you know that.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: Donald, do you know how to play this game? The reason I put in half the anti is because I don't know what I have got. Now play, or fold.

Dialogue: OK Gary, we call each other Kenny, all right?

Dialogue: All right, Kenny.

Speaker: dean
Dialogue: Can't you pull that stocking down further, Kenny?

Dialogue: It just cost me fifty quid to have this done.  If you think I am going to ruin it for a couple of old bastards you're mistaken, Kenny.

Dialogue: What are you doing, Kenny?

Dialogue: Finding out where he keeps the money.

Dialogue: Kenny, you twat, does it look like these people have got any money? They can't even afford new furniture. We've got the guns; now if you don't mind . . .

Dialogue: Ten grand blind.

Dialogue: Twenty thousand open.

Dialogue: I'll fold.

Dialogue: What?

Dialogue: I thought you said no staff, Bazza!

Dialogue: You should see what they did to poor Gary.

Dialogue: Gary, get back into the van!

Dialogue: Fifty grand.

Dialogue: Eighty grand.

Dialogue: One hundred grand.

Dialogue: Hold on fellas, I know . . .

Dialogue: That is quite a raise, one hundred and fifty on my hundred.

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: Yes . . . and is there something else you want to say? EDDY

Speaker: croupier
Dialogue: We will have to see both your cards if no one loans EDDY the money to continue. It's a loan or we see both your cards.

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: I will.

Dialogue: You will what?

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: I will loan you the money.

Dialogue: I think I would rather just turn them over.

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: I am not interested in what you would rather; I want to keep going. I am also offering you the money, so we don't have to turn them over because you can borrow.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: I need two hundred and fifty grand.

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: No, you need five hundred grand to see me.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: That's if I want to see you.

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: Well, you're going to have a problem carrying on, aintcha.

Speaker: cruopier
Dialogue: You can still fold.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: I'll see ya.

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: For half a million?

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: Unless you are going to accept twenty quid.

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: And still got a sense of humour. That's not monkey nuts son; you can still fold.  OK, before I loan you this, I expect, if you lose of course, my money back within a week, Crystal? That's Sunday, OK?

Speaker: croupier
Dialogue: Is that it?

Speaker: frazer
Dialogue: He was bluffing!

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: Let's see your fucking cards.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: I knew he was bluffing, but somehow the worst card player round the table had fucked me like a frozen virgin with a pair of sevens. A series of blows to my head with a baseball bat would have been greeted with a grin compared to this. Ten minutes earlier, I was two hundred thousand pounds richer; now I owed half a million.

Speaker: hatchet
Dialogue: I know your friends are responsible for most of that cash, so I'll give you all a week to find it. After that, I'll take a finger off each of you and your friend's hands for each day that passes without payment; and when you have all run out of digits, then who knows what?

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: This doesn't look good.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: I then explained the unfortunate position we were in. Harry was going to start sizing up all our fingers in a week, 'cause he knew there was no way I could raise that kind of money on my own. Harry saw it as their money on the table so it was also their debt off the table. I hate to admit it but I could have kissed the old bastard for that. If I said I wanted to settle this debt on my own it would have been a lie.

Speaker: eddy
Dialogue: Listen, I wish he would let me settle it on my own.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I'll kill him!

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: Stop fucking around, Tom, and think. What are we going to do?

Speaker: soap
Dialogue: What's all the fuss about Harry? Why don't we just boycott the payment?

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: Let me tell you about Hatchet Harry. Once there was this geezer called Smithy Robinson who worked for Harry. It was rumoured that he was on the take. Harry invited Smithy round for an explanation. Smithy didn't do a very good job. Within a minute Harry lost his temper and reached for the nearest thing at hand, which happened to be a fifteen-inch black rubber cock. He then proceeded to batter poor Smithy to death with this; that was seen as a pleasant way to go . . . Hence, Hatchet Harry is a man you pay if you owe.

Dialogue: Fod God's sake.

Dialogue: Sod you, you clean it up.

Dialogue: Sorry fellas, but that stupid cow!

Dialogue: Never mind, could you please just sit down and stay out of the way.

Speaker: winston
Dialogue: Anyway, how much do you want?

Speaker: plank
Dialogue: I am after a half weight.

Speaker: winston
Dialogue: That's one and a half thousand. Pass those scales, Willie, and sort out the gear, Charlie. Any chance of seeing your money?

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: The odds are one hundred to one so all we need is five grand.

Speaker: soap
Dialogue: I would rather put my money on a three-legged rocking horse. The odds are a hundred to one for a good reason, BACON . . . it won't win. So where is Ed with all the bright ideas?

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: At the bottom of a bottle and has been for two days; it's hit him hard.

Speaker: soap
Dialogue: It's hit us all hard!

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: Yeah, but he has got to tell his Dad he is about to lose his bar.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Listen to this one then; you open a company called the Arse Tickler's Faggot Fan Club. You take an advert in the back page of some gay mag, advertising the latest in arse-intruding dildos, sell it a bit with, er . . . I dunno, `does what no other dildo can do until now', latest and greatest in sexual technology. Guaranteed results or money back, all that bollocks. These dills cost twenty-five each; a snip for all the pleasure they are going to give the recipients. They send a cheque to the company name, nothing offensive, er, Bobbie's Bits or something, for twenty-five. You put these in the bank for two weeks and let them clear. Now this is the clever bit. Then you send back the cheques for twenty-five pounds from the real company name, Arse Tickler's Faggot Fan Club, saying sorry, we couldn't get the supply from America, they have sold out. Now you see how many of the people cash those cheques; not a single soul, because who wants his bank manager to know he tickles arses when he is not paying in cheques!

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: So how long do you have to wait 'till you see a return?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Probably no longer than four weeks.

Speaker: bacon
Dialogue: A month? So, my friend, what fucking good is that, if we need it in six . . . no, five days?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, it's still a good idea.

Speaker: soap
Dialogue: Listen to this one . . .

Dialogue: So do you know these geezers well?

Speaker: plank
Dialogue: Well enough. I have been buying gear off one of them for a couple of years.

Speaker: dog
Dialogue: What they like then?

Speaker: plank
Dialogue: Poofs. Nothing heavy, four public school guys. Soft as shite.

Speaker: soap
Dialogue: And you keep all the money'

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I have heard some fucking stupid ideas in my time but yours makes Bacon's sound inspired.

Speaker: plank
Dialogue: They ponce around in funny hippie clothes all day, talking bollocks. They're just good at growing weed, that's all, and business has got bigger than what they can keep up with.

Dialogue: If you're so fucking clever why don't you come up with a suggestion?

Dialogue: I am thinking, I am thinking.

Dialogue: Listen, they can't be all stupid if they got a container load of cash sitting in shoe boxes, a skip-load of Class A gear and you don't think there is anybody sensible involved.

Dialogue: There's one steel gate as you go in but they never lock it.

Dialogue: What do you know about Chris, eh? You put Big Chris on a job and he will make sure it gets done, no matter what's in his way. His dad used to collect debts and his dad before that, and that monster of a boy will after he has gone. It seems that the Almighty himself requested them to collect debts for eternity and not to fear knocking on old Nick's door himself, if he was behind on his payment. But he has never nicked a picker in his life. Straight as an arrow and as strong as the bow that fired it. If you dropped your tenner he would search till he found ya . . . the only problem is he isn't stable, has a temper like a runaway train, and he hits twice as hard. Heaven protect anyone who touches that boy, not that the boy needs protecting.

Dialogue: Yeah.

A few nights ago Rory's Roger iron rusted, so he has gone to the battle-cruiser to watch the end of a football game. Nobody is watching the custard so he has turned the channel over. A fat man's north opens and he wanders up and turns the Liza over. `Now fuck off and watch it somewhere else.' Rory knows claret is imminent, but he doesn't want to miss the end of the game; so, calm as a coma, he stands and picks up a fire extinguisher and he walks straight past the jam rolls who are ready for action, then he plonks it outside the entrance. He then orders an Aristotle of the most ping pong oddly in the nuclear sub and switches back to his footer. `That's fucking it,' says the man. Rory gobs out a mouthful of booze covering fatty; he flicks a flaming match into his bird's nest and the man lit up like a leaking gas pipe. Rory, unfazed, turned back to watch his game. The flaming man and his chinos ran outside to extinguish the flames, and Rory cheered on. His team won too, four-nil.
